title: Is spack usage without lsb_release?
body:
I am trying to use space on a Linux system where the command lsb_release returns nothing. This breaks spack.

-----

On the Los Alamos system the trinitite HPC system (a cray linux system) has a version of `lsb_release` in `/usr/bin` that returns
```
LSB Version:	n/a
```
when I use spack this causes a cascade of error, even during sourcing `$SPACK_ROOT/share/spack/setup-env.csh`

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Find a system where `lsb_release` doesn't return any information. This will break spack.

### Information on your system

This includes:
Trinitite is a an unclassified computing cluster for ASC code developers who target the Trinity platform. Cray CLE, based on SLES. The compute nodes run a Lightweight Operating System (LWOS), while both the (external) front-end nodes and (internal) login nodes run the fully featured OS. The Cray User Guide is a useful document for users and developers. See the Cray Documentation for complete information.     2 front-end nodes, external to the interconnect

    100 compute nodes with Intel Haswell processor, and
    100 compute nodes with an Intel Knights Landing (KNL) processor

    32 CPU cores per Haswell compute node (2x hyperthreads each), and
    68 CPU cores per KNL (4x hyperthreads each)

    Haswell, per node: 128 GB Memory,
    KNL, per node: 16 GB Multi-Channel Dynamic Random Access Memory (MCDRAM), aka. High-bandwidth memory (HBM)
    96 GB Double Data Rate Random Acess Memory (DDRAM)

    Peak speed = 100 HSW nodes * 32 cores * 2.3 GHz * 8 Flops/clock = 59 TFlops
    + 100 KNL nodes * 68 cores * 1.4 GHz * 2 FMAs/core * 16 ops/clock/FMA = 305 Tflops
    for a grand total of 364 TFlops*. 

I searched your documentation, but didn't find anything about this routine (lsb_release). Is there a workaround for this issue?
